query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 La gloria di colui che tutto move 2 per l’universo penetra, e risplende 3 in una parte più e meno altrove.
query.result:
**English:**
1 The glory of Him who moves all things 2 penetrates the universe, and shines 3 more in one part and less in another.
**Cornish:**
1 Klowr Neb a wra'gas movyans oll 2 a dreus an bys, ha'gas sklerys, 3 moy yn on rann ha le ages yn erel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
10 Veramente quant’ io del regno santo 11 ne la mia mente potei far tesoro, 12 sarà ora materia del mio canto.
query.result:
**English:**
10 Truly, as much as I was able to treasure in my mind 11 of the holy kingdom, 12 will now be the subject of my song.
**Cornish:**
10 Gwir, kyns na'm poos yn vy spyrys sanct, 11 a alla yn vy kov a alla gwir, 12 henna a vydh mater vy kan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
13 O buono Appollo, a l’ultimo lavoro 14 fammi del tuo valor sì fatto vaso, 15 come dimandi a dar l’amato alloro.
query.result:
**English:**
13 O good Apollo, for this final labor 14 make me such a vessel of your power, 15 as you require to grant the beloved laurel.
**Cornish:**
13 O Appollo da, rag an ober diwettha, 14 hemma vy gallu yn vy les, 15 dell yw kemer an lorrell serchys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
16 Infino a qui l’un giogo di Parnaso 17 assai mi fu; ma or con amendue 18 m’è uopo intrar ne l’aringo rimaso.
query.result:
**English:**
16 Up to this point, one peak of Parnassus 17 was enough for me; but now with both 18 I must enter the remaining arena.
**Cornish:**
16 Byttegyns henna, unn kodha a Barnassus 17 o wrug genough; mes lemmyn gans an dhew 18 yma'm besowgh mos dhe'n arenen wolow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
19 Entra nel petto mio, e spira tue 20 sì come quando Marsïa traesti 21 de la vagina de le membra sue.

Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
22 O divina virtù, se mi ti presti 23 tanto che l’ombra del beato regno 24 segnata nel mio capo io manifesti,
25 vedra’mi al piè del tuo diletto legno 26 venire, e coronarmi de le foglie 27 che la materia e tu mi farai degno.
query.result:
**English:**
22 O divine virtue, if you grant me 23 so much that the shadow of the blessed kingdom 24 marked in my head I manifest,
25 you will see me at the foot of your beloved tree 26 come, and crown myself with the leaves 27 that matter and you will make me worthy.
**Cornish:**
22 O devynnerth, mar pleg ty dhynnerghys 23 kyns na'n keffrys a'n ryes bys vyth 24 merkys yn fen ow fenowgh,
25 whylowgh vy dhe'th pew an pren ker, 26 ow tos ha bos ha'n delyow 27 a wra dhe dhym ha t'eva dhe'm gwella.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
28 Sì rade volte, padre, se ne coglie 29 per trïunfare o cesare o poeta, 30 colpa e vergogna de l’umane voglie,
31 che parturir letizia in su la lieta 32 delfica deïtà dovria la fronda 33 peneia, quando alcun di sé asseta.
query.result:
**English:**
28 So rarely, father, is it gathered 29 to triumph over either Caesar or poet, 30 fault and shame of human desires,
31 that the laurel wreath, which should produce joy in the joyful 32 Delphic deity, ought to bear the Peneian leaf, 33 whenever someone is crowned with it.
**Cornish:**
28 Mor a-ugh, tas, y feuir, 29 rag tremen orth cesar poes, 30 gwall ha mes a'n dhymmanolgow,
31 rag gorra lowen war an lowen 32 doweth Delphos, dyllo dhe'n wra 33 pren Peneus, pub vyth onan a-ugh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
34 Poca favilla gran fiamma seconda: 35 forse di retro a me con miglior voci 36 si pregherà perché Cirra risponda.
query.result:
**English:**
34 A small spark can kindle a great flame: 35 perhaps after me, with a better voice, 36 someone will pray so that Cirra will answer.
**Cornish:**
34 Tanow byghan a wra tanow bras: 35 efalla, wosa'm, gans leveryow gwell, 36 bydh pednans rag Cirra dhe'n gorra.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
37 Surge ai mortali per diverse foci 38 la lucerna del mondo; ma da quella 39 che quattro cerchi giugne con tre croci,
40 con miglior corso e con migliore stella 41 esce congiunta, e la mondana cera 42 più a suo modo tempera e suggella.
query.result:
**English:**
37 The lamp of the world rises for mortals from different hearths; 38 but from the one 39 that joins four circles with three crosses,
40 with a better course and a better star 41 it comes forth conjoined, and the worldly wax 42 it tempers and seals more to its liking.
**Cornish:**
37 Y'n sevel orth an dusow gans tanowow dyffrans; 38 mes a'n onan 39 a jun tyller pedwar kelg gans teyr kryjyow,
40 gans kours gwell ha gans steren gwell 41 y feu an keth, ha'n keth an bys 42 y temper ha'y sel orth moy dhe'y fordh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
43 Fatto avea di là mane e di qua sera 44 tal foce, e quasi tutto era là bianco 45 quello emisperio, e l’altra parte nera,
46 quando Beatrice in sul sinistro fianco 47 vidi rivolta e riguardar nel sole: 48 aguglia sì non li s’affisse unquanco.
query.result:
**English:**
43 It had made morning there and evening here, 44 such that, and almost all white was there 45 that hemisphere, and the other part black,
46 when Beatrice on my left side 47 I saw turned and gazing at the sun: 48 never did an eagle fix itself so intently on it.
**Cornish:**
43 Gwreys o ena oedh myttin ha'n ena oedh nos 44 keth fordh, ha bron war oll gwyn 45 an hanter-bys na, ha'n hanter aral du,
46 pub gwelys vy Beatrice war ow dhelergh 47 ow treylya ha ow sel orth an howl: 48 hebma na'n er owth a-ugh owth dhe'y fordh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
49 E sì come secondo raggio suole 50 uscir del primo e risalire in suso, 51 pur come pelegrin che tornar vuole,
52 così de l’atto suo, per li occhi infuso 53 ne l’imagine mia, il mio si fece, 54 e fissi li occhi al sole oltre nostr’ uso.
query.result:
**English:**
49 And just as a second ray is wont 50 to issue from the first and rise again upwards, 51 just like a pilgrim who wants to return,
52 so from her action, infused through her eyes 53 into my image, mine was made, 54 and I fixed my eyes on the sun beyond our custom.
**Cornish:**
49 Ha kepar ha'n eyl a-ugh a wra 50 ow tos a'n kynsa ha ow sevel orth, 51 kepar pererin a wra dyllo dhe'y fordh,
52 keth fordh a'y ober, ow tos dhe'y hedhow 53 yn ow ymage, owth hemma a wra gwreys, 54 ha'm selys ow hedhow orth an howl dre hevowgh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
55 Molto è licito là, che qui non lece 56 a le nostre virtù, mercé del loco 57 fatto per proprio de l’umana spece.
query.result:
**English:**
55 Much is permitted there, which here is not allowed 56 to our virtues, thanks to the place 57 made specifically for the human race.
**Cornish:**
55 Lies yw leel dhe, na wra leel ama 56 dhe'n nerthowgh ni, dre ras an le, 57 gwreys rag unn dhe'n dusowgh denel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
64 Beatrice tutta ne l’etterne rote 65 fissa con li occhi stava; e io in lei 66 le luci fissi, di là sù rimote.
query.result:
**English:**
64 Beatrice stood with her eyes fixed on the eternal wheels; 65 and I fixed my eyes on her, 66 far removed from up there.
**Cornish:**
64 Beatrice a sevel gans hedhow dhe'n keglow treweyth, 65 ha'm sevel vy dhe'y hedhow, a-dhia dhe'n-dro. 66 A-dhia dhe'n-dro a-ugh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
67 Nel suo aspetto tal dentro mi fei, 68 qual si fé Glauco nel gustar de l’erba 69 che ’l fé consorto in mar de li altri dèi.
query.result:
**English:**
67 In her aspect I became such within, 68 as Glaucus became on tasting the herb 69 that made him a companion of the other gods in the sea.
**Cornish:**
67 Yn y golwg henna y'm gwreys keth, 68 kepar ha Glaucus pub teves an losow 69 a wra henna owth dhe'n mor yn keth an dusow aral.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
70 Trasumanar significar per verba 71 non si poria; però l’essemplo basti 72 a cui esperïenza grazia serba.
query.result:
**English:**
70 To signify transcendence through words 71 would not be possible; therefore, let the example suffice 72 for one to whom grace grants experience.
**Cornish:**
70 Treusmen an golgh a synsi orth an ger 71 nyns yw possybyl; rag an ensampel a wra 72 dhe unn dheth gras a wra profys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
73 S’i’ era sol di me quel che creasti 74 novellamente, amor che ’l ciel governi, 75 tu ’l sai, che col tuo lume mi levasti.
query.result:
**English:**
73 If I was alone in being that which you created 74 anew, love that governs the heavens, 75 you know it, for with your light you raised me up.
**Cornish:**
73 Mar ow kowsel unn a'm beu cresas 74 nowydh, karanteth ow a wra govern an nef, 75 ty a wra gesys, rag orth an golgh ow a'm sevas.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
76 Quando la rota che tu sempiterni 77 desiderato, a sé mi fece atteso 78 con l’armonia che temperi e discerni,
79 parvemi tanto allor del cielo acceso 80 de la fiamma del sol, che pioggia o fiume 81 lago non fece alcun tanto disteso.
query.result:
**English:**
76 When the wheel that you make eternal, 77 desired one, drew me to itself 78 with the harmony that you moderate and discern,
79 then it seemed to me that heaven was so kindled 80 by the flame of the sun that no rain or river 81 or lake ever made anything so vast.
**Cornish:**
76 Pyth pan vlydhen an ros ow a wra sempiterna 77 a-dhyskynnys, dhe dhe'm gul dhe'n golgh, 78 orth an harmoni ow a wra temperya ha dyskwedhes,
79 ytho henna dhe'm nevra an nef o flamm an howl, 80 na glaw po avon 81 po lynn nyns a wra mar dha vast.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
82 La novità del suono e ’l grande lume 83 di lor cagion m’accesero un disio 84 mai non sentito di cotanto acume.
query.result:
**English:**
82 The novelty of the sound and the great light 83 of their source kindled in me a desire 84 never before felt with such intensity.
**Cornish:**
82 An nowydh a'n son ha'n golgh meur 83 a'ga reson a wra'm gul dysyr 84 nyns eus ve gesys bythkweth avel henna.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
85 Ond’ ella, che vedea me sì com’ io, 86 a quïetarmi l’animo commosso, 87 pria ch’io a dimandar, la bocca aprio
88 e cominciò: «Tu stesso ti fai grosso 89 col falso imaginar, sì che non vedi 90 ciò che vedresti se l’avessi scosso.
query.result:
**English:**
85 Then she, who saw me just as I was, 86 to calm my troubled soul, 87 before I asked a question, opened her mouth
88 and began: “You yourself make yourself dense 89 with false imagining, so that you do not see 90 what you would see if you had shaken it off.
**Cornish:**
85 Ha henna, ow a wra'm gweles dell ow kowsa, 86 dhe'm gorra'm enef kommosys, 87 kyns ow kovsa dhe'm gorra, ytho henna a wra gorra'y benow
88 ha komensa: “Ty a wra gul de'n gros 89 orth an fals ombrofya, dell nyns a wra gweles 90 henna ow a wra gweles mar tussa'y skothys.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 Tu non se’ in terra, sì come tu credi; 92 ma folgore, fuggendo il proprio sito, 93 non corse come tu ch’ad esso riedi».
query.result:
**English:**
91 You are not on earth, as you believe; 92 but lightning, fleeing its proper place, 93 did not race as you do, who are returning to it.
**Cornish:**
91 Nyns eus vy yn-n an nor, dell henna a grys; 92 mes fulgor, ow a wra floya y'n le unn, 93 nyns a wra resek dell henna a wra dyllo dhe'n golgh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
94 S’io fui del primo dubbio disvestito 95 per le sorrise parolette brevi, 96 dentro ad un nuovo più fu’ inretito
97 e dissi: «Già contento requïevi 98 di grande ammirazion; ma ora ammiro 99 com’ io trascenda questi corpi levi».
query.result:
**English:**
94 If I was freed from my first doubt 95 by the brief, smiling words, 96 I was ensnared even more by a new one
97 and I said: “I was once content and at rest 98 in great wonder; but now I marvel 99 at how I transcend these light bodies.”
**Cornish:**
94 Mar ow kowsa unn a'm beu divestedh 95 orth an parolow bysk serrys, 96 mes y'n-n unn nowydh moy o flammys
97 ha me a leveris: “Yn-n unn prys ow kowsa unn soth, 98 yn-n meur admirys; mes lemmyn ow admir 99 pyth pan owth transcenda an korpow ma.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
100 Ond’ ella, appresso d’un pïo sospiro, 101 li occhi drizzò ver’ me con quel sembiante 102 che madre fa sovra figlio deliro,
103 e cominciò: «Le cose tutte quante 104 hanno ordine tra loro, e questo è forma 105 che l’universo a Dio fa simigliante.
query.result:
**English:**
100 Then, after a deep sigh, 101 she turned her eyes toward me with the look 102 that a mother gives her delirious child,
103 and began: “All things have order among themselves, 104 and this is the form 105 that makes the universe resemble God.
**Cornish:**
100 Ha henna, wosa unn pïo sospiro, 101 li occhi a wra dryjya dhe'n golgh orth vy orth an semblyans 102 ow a wra mam a wra gul orth mab deliro,
103 ha commensis: “An traow oll a wra unn urdh yntredho, 104 ha henna yw an form 105 ow a wra an bys dhe Dhew a wra symylyans.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
106 Qui veggion l’alte creature l’orma 107 de l’etterno valore, il qual è fine 108 al quale è fatta la toccata norma.
query.result:
**English:**
106 Here the high creatures see the imprint 107 of the eternal value, which is the end 108 for which the created order was made.
**Cornish:**
106 Ama yma an uhel kreatur a wra gweles an orma 107 a'n eternel valor, ow yw an fin 108 dhe unn dheth yw an norma a wra gul.

**English:**
109 In the order of which I speak, all 110 natures are inclined, by different lots, 111 more or less close to their source;
112 hence they move toward different ports 113 across the great sea of being, and each one 114 with an instinct given to it that guides it.
**Cornish:**
109 Yn-n an urdh owth leveris, oll 110 natur a wra ynklyn, orth sortys dyffrans, 111 moy po'ga prinsip a wra ha moy po'ga vess.
112 Rag henna a wra movyas dhe'n portow dyffrans 113 orth an mor meur a'n bys, ha pub unn 114 orth unn istinkt a wra gul dheth ow a wra gul porti.

**English:**
121 Providence, which arranges all things so well, 122 with its light makes the heavens ever tranquil, 123 in which revolves that which has the greatest speed;
124 and now there, as if to a decreed place, 125 the power of that cord carries us, 126 which directs whatever it shoots to a happy mark.
**Cornish:**
121 An Ragfurvys, neb a wrapp pub tra, 122 a wra an nef a'n keunf bys vyth, 123 y'n neb a droel an re beu fressa.
124 Ha lemmyn, dell yw an le unn, 125 an gallus a'n gordh na'n keunf, 126 a wra pub tra a skoedh dhe'n merk lowen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
127 Vero è che, come forma non s’accorda 128 molte fïate a l’intenzion de l’arte, 129 perch’ a risponder la materia è sorda,
130 così da questo corso si diparte 131 talor la creatura, c’ha podere 132 di piegar, così pinta, in altra parte;
133 e sì come veder si può cadere 134 foco di nube, sì l’impeto primo 135 l’atterra torto da falso piacere.
query.result:
**English:**
127 It is true that, just as form does not always 128 accord with the intention of the artist, 129 because matter is deaf to the call,
130 so sometimes the creature, which has the power 131 to turn aside, being thus impelled, 132 departs from this course;
133 and just as fire can be seen to fall 134 from a cloud, so the first impetus 135 knocks it down, twisted by false pleasure.
**Cornish:**
127 Gwir yw, dell dell yw furv na'n jev, 128 lies bys vyth dhe'n menowgh an artys, 129 rag an mater a's teves dowsen.
130 Dell yw an kreadur a wra'n keth, 131 neb a wra gallus dhe'n droel, 132 dhe'n droel dhe'n keth, a wra'n keth.
133 Ha dell yw tan a weler tan dhe'n keunf, 134 tan a'n keunf, dell yw an kynsa hwithrans, 135 a wra'n keth dhe'n nor dhe'n pleser gol.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
136 Non dei più ammirar, se bene stimo, 137 lo tuo salir, se non come d’un rivo 138 se d’alto monte scende giuso ad imo.
query.result:
**English:**
136 You should not marvel more, if I judge well, 137 at your ascent, than at that of a river 138 which descends from a high mountain to the bottom.
**Cornish:**
136 Na dhfya moy kemmyska, mar yw vyth barn, 137 dha vos dhe'n nef, marnas dell yw avon 138 a wra a-ves menydh ughel dhe'n nor.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
139 Maraviglia sarebbe in te se, privo 140 d’impedimento, giù ti fossi assiso, 141 com’ a terra quïete in foco vivo».
query.result:
**English:**
139 It would be a marvel in you if, deprived 140 of impediment, you had sat down below, 141 like quiet earth in living fire.
**Cornish:**
139 Marvil vythsa dhe'th, mar vyth heb let, 140 ty a vyth esedh isel, 141 dell yw nor dowr y'n tan byw.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
142 Quinci rivolse inver’ lo cielo il viso.
query.result:
**English:**
142 Then he turned his face towards heaven.
**Cornish:**
142 Wosa henna, ev a droes y'n vis dhe'n nef.
